utterances: I think as long as he fails to pursue the confrontation aspect of the policy, his ability to pursue the cooperation part of it will be hampered.
Congress forced Trump's hand recently by sending him a bill with new sanctions against Russia.
Trump grudgingly signed.
He said it would make it harder for him to strike good deals without saying what he had in mind.
Greg Myre, NPR News, Washington.
(SOUNDBITE OF DIRTY PROJECTORS SONG, ""STILLNESS IS THE MOVE"")
An unmarked corporate jet left a Mexican border town last night in great secrecy, bound for the United States.
The prisoner on board - one of the world's wealthiest, most ruthless and powerful drug kingpins.
His name - Joaquin Guzman.
He's also known as El Chapo, and he was extradited and will stand trial in a U.S.
federal court.
NPR's Carrie Kahn has followed El Chapo's remarkable story for years, and she joins us now from Mexico City.
Good morning, Carrie.
Good morning.
Tell us more about what we know of what transpired last night.
Well, word came down late yesterday afternoon that Guzman was on that plane to the U.S.
It was a surprise and not really.
He and his lawyers have been fighting this extradition ever since he was recaptured by Mexican marines early last year.
So this has been going on for a year.
According to Mexican prosecutors, Guzman had lost his last appeal, the last legal maneuver he had, yesterday, and he was already right at the border.
He was moved from a maximum security prison last year to that federal facility near the border in Ciudad Juarez, which is right across from El Paso, Texas.
(Foreign language spoken)
Well, these guidelines were published for a couple of reasons: One, we knew that, still, less than 30 percent of victims of cardiac arrest were receiving any form of bystander CPR.
We know CPR works and can double or triple survival from cardiac arrest and yet bystanders were hesitating to act.
When actual bystanders were questioned on why they didn't act, the most common reason was that they were afraid of doing something wrong.
So we felt that we really had to reassure bystanders that doing something was better than doing nothing.
And then, there were a couple of studies published that showed that against a historic control, compression-only CPR produced equivalent survival to conventional CPR.
So the science advisory was issued for bystander CPR for adults who collapse suddenly.
So give us a little ABCs of someone who - maybe in a shopping mall or wherever and see someone else collapse.
What would - give us the sequence we should do here.
If you see someone collapse suddenly and they're unresponsive, You should either call 911 if you're alone or send someone to call 911.

And then, if you're untrained or you're trained and not confident in your skills in compression and ventilation, you should compress-only, and that means put one heel of your hand in the center of the victim's chest between the nipple line.
Put the second heel on top.
It's best when you're kneeling to - kneel with your shoulders over your hand so that you can push straight down, you push hard and push fast.
It's almost impossible with an adult victim for you to push too hard.
And you should push at a rate of 100 times per minute.
We've often said that that's to the beat of ""Staying Alive,"" the Bee Gees song.
So, it's 100 compressions a minute.
You keep doing those compressions until either the victim starts to move or an AED arrives with other rescuers that can help or trained rescuers arrive and take over the care of the victim.
John in Jamesville, Wisconsin.
Hi, John.
Hey.
Hi, Ira.
Hi there.
I'm so excited to hear this on the radio.
And I'm hoping that Dr. Kalem(ph) here in town is listening too.
Have you got a comment for us?
What's that?
Have you got a question for us?
No, just a comment.

The caller is sighting - and I guess, rightly, she's sighting how there's no particular difference in studies so far with survival rates, but we've been doing compression-only CPR in Rock and Walworth County for about two years now.
And real, real cardiac arrests that fall within the study - we're getting 74 percent of those people walking out of the hospital that are getting good bystander compressions and compression-only CPR.

And I'm here to tell you these people versus what we used to do with over-ventilating people and decreasing the amount of refill into their hearts - these people are pinking up, and if there's any, any amount of oxygen left in their brains, they're having a really good neurological outcomes.
So I take it that you're a paramedic then.
I am.
Your results are consistent with those that we've been hearing about from EMS systems all over the country since the production of the 2005 guidelines.
There's just no question that previous guidelines did not emphasize compression sufficiently.
And so, in reeducating, paramedics and providers about the importance of chest compression, we are seeing dramatic improvements in survival from sudden cardiac arrest.
So, that's…

Just as important though is, even when we are able to get an advanced airway in, it's part of our big push or what we're really trying to do is decreasing the severity and frequency of respiration once that airway is made, because we're really finding that it's decreasing the refill on the heart.
And we're losing ground every time somebody pushes real hard and takes up space in that chest.
Right, there's no question that the emphasis on minimizing interruption in chest compression since 2005 has been on the right track, and it's really making a difference in survival.
This hands-only CPR, I want to be sure that we don't confuse the listeners - the hands-only CPR recommendation is for bystanders in the pre-hospital setting who witness adult sudden cardiac collapse.

It does not apply to infants and children, and does not apply to adult victims who have a respiratory cause of arrest because they're - they don't have as much oxygen in the blood at the time of the arrest, and we think they need a combination of compression and ventilation.
And right now, the American Heart Association still recommends conventional CPR for health care providers especially in the hospital, but we're gathering more data all the time.
Let me - we're running out of time.
I want to ask you, Mary, one last question if I have time.
What about people who are afraid of hurting?
You know, I'm going to break his breastbone.
I'm going to break her rib if I press too hard, something like that.

That's a great point, and it - good compressions may result in rib fractures, but it's very important to know that when somebody collapses and they're in cardiac arrest, they are dying, and they will likely die if you don't intervene.
So it's hard to make things worse than death.
Mm-hmm.
I…
Doing something's better than doing nothing and you may save a life.
And how much survival rate has it changed?
What can we expect?
This morning in Blacksburg, Virginia, a bell rang out at 9:45.
(Soundbite of bell ringing)
And when we visit another station, KDKA, we find more huge ad buys.
Oh, absolutely.
There's a campaign, and you can go online to Americanheart.org/handsonlycpr.
We'd also like to encourage people to learn CPR.
You can obtain a tip with your mannequin and you can learn from a DVD in less than 30 minutes in the comfort of your own home.
Let me ask you a question from ""Second Life,"" Jasmine(ph) asks, how long can compression-only CPR be given before you need to ventilate?
Well, we're gathering data on that.
We think that compression-only is very effective for the first minutes of CPR.
Certainly, we think for about the first three to four minutes after adult cardiac arrest, and may be effective for the first five or six minutes.
And hopefully by then, trained rescuers will arrive.
But we still need more data, and we're gathering that.
And Laura(ph) from ""Second Life"" also asks something I think a lot of us are thinking that make sense.
Are two bystanders doing CPR together better, and why?
Well, continuous chest compressions and giving effective chest compressions is tiring.
So if rescuers can relieve one another every couple of minutes that would be - that's a good idea.
And as far as opening the airway first, don't even - don't think about that, just go right into the compressions?
Well, again, if rescuers are untrained or they're unsure of their skills, they should go - bystanders should go to compression.
If a rescuer is trained and confident in their skills, they can either use the conventional CPR, which would include opening the airway and giving breath or they could do compression-only CPR.
And you think this will help people who are more or less would like to do something, but they're afraid?
We think this will make it easier, and we're hoping to encourage people to act, that action - doing something is better than doing nothing.
Well, Mary, I want to wish you luck, and thank you for taking the time to be with us today.
Ira, thank you so much.
I appreciate being with you today.
You're very welcome.
Mary Fran Hazinski is a clinical nurse specialist in pediatric emergency and critical care at Vanderbilt Children's Hospital in Nashville.
She's also a senior science editor at the American Heart Association.
We're going to take a break and change gear, and we're going to talk about the secret world of soil where researchers have - they found hundreds of soil bacteria that actually eat antibiotics.
You'd think the antibiotics would kill the bacteria, right?
No. They eat them for lunch and grow and thrive.
And we'll find out what this means.
Should we be afraid?
What does this mean about, you know, disease-resistant bacteria?
We'll talk about it.
Stay with us, we'll be right back.
I'm Ira Flatow.
This is TALK OF THE NATION: SCIENCE FRIDAY from NPR News.
